result.markdown:
# Notes {.unnumbered} ## Introduction :::{.callout-note} This is a long chapter, these notes are intended as a tour of main ideas! ::: ![Panda bus tour!](images/pandabus.jpg){width=300px} * Pandas is a major tool in Python data analysis * Works with Numpy, adding support for tabular / heterogenous data ## Import conventions: ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pandas as pd ``` ::: ## Panda's primary data structures * Series: One dimensional object containing a sequence of values of the same type. * DataFrame: Tabular data, similar (and inspired by) R dataframe. * Other structures will be introduced as they arise, e.g. Index and Groupby objects. ### Series ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj = pd.Series([4,7,-4,3], index = ["A","B","C","D"]) obj ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=47} ``` A 4 B 7 C -4 D 3 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: The `index` is optional, if not specified it will default to 0 through N-1 #### Selection Select elements or sub-Series by labels, sets of labels, boolean arrays ... ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj['A'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=48} ``` 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj[['A','C']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=49} ``` A 4 C -4 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj[obj > 3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=50} ``` A 4 B 7 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: #### Other things you can do * Numpy functions and Numpy-like operations work as expected: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj*3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=51} ``` A 12 B 21 C -12 D 9 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} np.exp(obj) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=52} ``` A 54.598150 B 1096.633158 C 0.018316 D 20.085537 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: * Series can be created from and converted to a dictionary ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj.to_dict() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=53} ``` {'A': 4, 'B': 7, 'C': -4, 'D': 3} ``` ::: ::: * Series can be converted to numpy array: ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj.to_numpy() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=54} ``` array([ 4, 7, -4, 3], dtype=int64) ``` ::: ::: ### DataFrame * Represents table of data * Has row index *index* and column index *column* * Common way to create is from a dictionary, but see *Table 5.1* for more! ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} test = pd.DataFrame({"cars":['Chevy','Ford','Dodge','BMW'],'MPG':[14,15,16,12], 'Year':[1979, 1980, 2001, 2020]}) test ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=55} ```{=html}
cars MPG Year
0 Chevy 14 1979
1 Ford 15 1980
2 Dodge 16 2001
3 BMW 12 2020
``` ::: ::: * If you want a non-default index, it can be specified just like with Series. * `head(n)` / `tail(n)` - return the first / last n rows, 5 by default #### Selecting * Can retrieve columns or sets of columns by using `obj[...]`: ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} test['cars'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=56} ``` 0 Chevy 1 Ford 2 Dodge 3 BMW Name: cars, dtype: object ``` ::: ::: Note that we got a `Series` here. ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} test[['cars','MPG']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=57} ```{=html}
cars MPG
0 Chevy 14
1 Ford 15
2 Dodge 16
3 BMW 12
``` ::: ::: * Dot notation can also be used (`test.cars`) as long as the column names are valid identifiers * *Rows* can be retrieved with `iloc[...]` and `loc[...]`: - `loc` retrieves by index - `iloc` retrieves by position. #### Modifying / Creating Columns * Columns can be modified (and created) by assignment: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} test['MPG^2'] = test['MPG']**2 test ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=58} ```{=html}
cars MPG Year MPG^2
0 Chevy 14 1979 196
1 Ford 15 1980 225
2 Dodge 16 2001 256
3 BMW 12 2020 144
``` ::: ::: * `del` keyword can be used to drop columns, or `drop` method can be used to do so non-destructively ### Index object * Index objects are used for holding axis labels and other metadata ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.index ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=59} ``` RangeIndex(start=0, stop=4, step=1) ``` ::: ::: * Can change the index, in this case replacing the default: ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Create index from one of the columns test.index = test['cars'] # remove 'cars' column since i am using as an index now. s test=test.drop('cars', axis = "columns") # or axis = 1 test ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=60} ```{=html}
MPG Year MPG^2
cars
Chevy 14 1979 196
Ford 15 1980 225
Dodge 16 2001 256
BMW 12 2020 144
``` ::: ::: * Note the `axis` keyword argument above, many DataFrame methods use this. * Above I changed a column into an index. Often you want to go the other way, this can be done with `reset_index`: ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.reset_index() # Note this doesn't actually change test ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=61} ```{=html}
cars MPG Year MPG^2
0 Chevy 14 1979 196
1 Ford 15 1980 225
2 Dodge 16 2001 256
3 BMW 12 2020 144
``` ::: ::: * Columns are an index as well: ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.columns ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=62} ``` Index(['MPG', 'Year', 'MPG^2'], dtype='object') ``` ::: ::: * Indexes act like immutable sets, see *Table 5.2* in book for Index methods and properties ## Essential Functionality ### Reindexing and dropping * `reindex` creats a *new* object with the values arranged according to the new index. Missing values are used if necessary, or you can use optional fill methods. You can use `iloc` and `loc` to reindex as well. ::: {.cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} s = pd.Series([1,2,3,4,5], index = list("abcde")) s2 = s.reindex(list("abcfu")) # not a song by GAYLE s2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=63} ``` a 1.0 b 2.0 c 3.0 f NaN u NaN dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: * Missing values and can be tested for with `isna` or `notna` methods ::: {.cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} pd.isna(s2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=64} ``` a False b False c False f True u True dtype: bool ``` ::: ::: * `drop` , illustrated above can drop rows or columns. In addition to using `axis` you can use `columns` or `index`. Again these make copies. ::: {.cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.drop(columns = 'MPG') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=65} ```{=html}
Year MPG^2
cars
Chevy 1979 196
Ford 1980 225
Dodge 2001 256
BMW 2020 144
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.drop(index = ['Ford', 'BMW']) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=66} ```{=html}
MPG Year MPG^2
cars
Chevy 14 1979 196
Dodge 16 2001 256
``` ::: ::: ### Indexing, Selection and Filtering #### Series * For Series, indexing is similar to Numpy, except you can use the index as well as integers. ::: {.cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj = pd.Series(np.arange(4.), index=["a", "b", "c", "d"]) obj[0:3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=67} ``` a 0.0 b 1.0 c 2.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj['a':'c'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=68} ``` a 0.0 b 1.0 c 2.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj[obj<2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=69} ``` a 0.0 b 1.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj[['a','d']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=70} ``` a 0.0 d 3.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: * *However*, preferred way is to use `loc` for selection by *index* and `iloc` for selection by position. This is to avoid the issue where the `index` is itself integers. ::: {.cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj.loc[['a','d']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=71} ``` a 0.0 d 3.0 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} obj.iloc[1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=72} ``` 1.0 ``` ::: ::: :::{.callout-note} Note if a range or a set of indexes is used, a Series is returned. If a single item is requested, you get just that item. ::: #### DataFrame * Selecting with `df[...]` for a DataFrame retrieves one or more columns as we have seen, if you select a single column you get a Series * There are some special cases, indexing with a boolean selects *rows*, as does selecting with a slice: ::: {.cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} test[0:1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=73} ```{=html}
MPG Year MPG^2
cars
Chevy 14 1979 196
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} test[test['MPG'] < 15] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=74} ```{=html}
MPG Year MPG^2
cars
Chevy 14 1979 196
BMW 12 2020 144
``` ::: ::: * `iloc` and `loc` can be used to select rows as illustrated before, but can also be used to select columns or subsets of rows/columns ::: {.cell execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.loc[:,['Year','MPG']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=75} ```{=html}
Year MPG
cars
Chevy 1979 14
Ford 1980 15
Dodge 2001 16
BMW 2020 12
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.loc['Ford','MPG'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=76} ``` 15 ``` ::: ::: * These work with slices and booleans as well! The following says "give me all the rows with MPG more then 15, and the columns starting from Year" ::: {.cell execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.loc[test['MPG'] > 15, 'Year':] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=77} ```{=html}
Year MPG^2
cars
Dodge 2001 256
``` ::: ::: * Indexing options are fully illustrated in the book and *Table 5.4* * Be careful with *chained indexing*: ::: {.cell execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} test[test['MPG']> 15].loc[:,'MPG'] = 18 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\indexing.py:1843: SettingWithCopyWarning: A value is trying to be set on a copy of a slice from a DataFrame. Try using .loc[row_indexer,col_indexer] = value instead See the caveats in the documentation: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#returning-a-view-versus-a-copy self.obj[item_labels[indexer[info_axis]]] = value ``` ::: ::: Here we are assigning to a 'slice', which is probably not what is intended. You will get a warning and a recommendation to fix it by using one `loc`: ::: {.cell execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.loc[test['MPG']> 15 ,'MPG'] = 18 test ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=79} ```{=html}
MPG Year MPG^2
cars
Chevy 14 1979 196
Ford 15 1980 225
Dodge 18 2001 256
BMW 12 2020 144
``` ::: ::: :::{.callout-tip} ### Rule of Thumb Avoid chained indexing when doing assignments ::: ### Arithmetic and Data Alignment * Pandas can make it simpler to work with objects that have different indexes, usually 'doing the right thing' ::: {.cell execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} s1 = pd.Series([7.3, -2.5, 3.4, 1.5], index=["a", "c", "d", "e"]) s2 = pd.Series([-2.1, 3.6, -1.5, 4, 3.1], index=["a", "c", "e", "f", "g"]) s1+s2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=80} ``` a 5.2 c 1.1 d NaN e 0.0 f NaN g NaN dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: * Fills can be specified by using methods: ::: {.cell execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} s1.add(s2, fill_value = 0) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=81} ``` a 5.2 c 1.1 d 3.4 e 0.0 f 4.0 g 3.1 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: * See *Table 5.5* for list of these methods. * You can also do arithmetic between *DataFrame*s and *Series* in a way that is similar to Numpy. ### Function Application and Mapping * Numpy *ufuncs* also work with Pandas objects. ::: {.cell execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} frame = pd.DataFrame(np.random.standard_normal((4, 3)), columns=list("bde"), index=["Utah", "Ohio", "Texas", "Oregon"]) frame ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=82} ```{=html}
b d e
Utah -0.395311 -1.245540 0.537222
Ohio -1.105675 -1.554810 1.175839
Texas 1.171251 2.175225 -0.465866
Oregon 0.258185 0.154549 -0.119907
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} np.abs(frame) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=83} ```{=html}
b d e
Utah 0.395311 1.245540 0.537222
Ohio 1.105675 1.554810 1.175839
Texas 1.171251 2.175225 0.465866
Oregon 0.258185 0.154549 0.119907
``` ::: ::: * `apply` can be used to apply a function on 1D arrays to each column or row: ::: {.cell execution_count=39} ``` {.python .cell-code} frame.apply(np.max, axis = 'rows') #'axis' is optional here, default is rows ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=84} ``` b 1.171251 d 2.175225 e 1.175839 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Applying accross columns is common, especially to combine different columns in some way: ::: {.cell execution_count=40} ``` {.python .cell-code} frame['max'] = frame.apply(np.max, axis = 'columns') frame ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=85} ```{=html}
b d e max
Utah -0.395311 -1.245540 0.537222 0.537222
Ohio -1.105675 -1.554810 1.175839 1.175839
Texas 1.171251 2.175225 -0.465866 2.175225
Oregon 0.258185 0.154549 -0.119907 0.258185
``` ::: ::: * Many more examples of this in the book. ### Sorting and Ranking * `sort_index` will sort with the index (on either axis for *DataFrame*) * `sort_values` is used to sort by values or a particular column ::: {.cell execution_count=41} ``` {.python .cell-code} test.sort_values('MPG') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=86} ```{=html}
MPG Year MPG^2
cars
BMW 12 2020 144
Chevy 14 1979 196
Ford 15 1980 225
Dodge 18 2001 256
``` ::: ::: * `rank` will assign ranks from on through the number of data points. ## Summarizing and Computing Descriptive Statistics ::: {.cell execution_count=42} ``` {.python .cell-code} df = pd.DataFrame([[1.4, np.nan], [7.1, -4.5], [np.nan, np.nan], [0.75, -1.3]], index=["a", "b", "c", "d"], columns=["one", "two"]) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=87} ```{=html}
one two
a 1.40 NaN
b 7.10 -4.5
c NaN NaN
d 0.75 -1.3
``` ::: ::: Some Examples: Sum over rows: ::: {.cell execution_count=43} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=88} ``` one 9.25 two -5.80 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Sum over columns: ::: {.cell execution_count=44} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Sum Rows df.sum(axis="columns") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=89} ``` a 1.40 b 2.60 c 0.00 d -0.55 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Extremely useful is `describe`: ::: {.cell execution_count=45} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=90} ```{=html}
one two
count 3.000000 2.000000
mean 3.083333 -2.900000
std 3.493685 2.262742
min 0.750000 -4.500000
25% 1.075000 -3.700000
50% 1.400000 -2.900000
75% 4.250000 -2.100000
max 7.100000 -1.300000
``` ::: ::: **Book chapter contains *many* more examples and a full list of summary statistics and related methods.** ## Summary * Primary Panda's data structures: - Series - DataFrame * Many ways to access and transform these objects. Key ones are: - `[]` : access an element(s) of a `Series` or columns(s) of a `DataFrame` - `loc[r ,c]` : access a row / column / cell by the `index`. - `iloc[i, j]` : access ar row / column / cell by the integer position. * [Online reference.](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/index.html) :::{.callout-tip} ## Suggestion Work though the chapter's code and try stuff! ::: ## References * [Chapter's code.](https://nbviewer.org/github/pydata/pydata-book/blob/3rd-edition/ch05.ipynb) * [Panda reference.](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/index.html) ## Next Chapter * Loading and writing data sets!
